H.industrial_ru: Used in ammonia production (Haber process), oil refining, and as a clean energy carrier in hydrogen fuel cells.
H.production_ru: Primarily produced by steam methane reforming; also by water electrolysis using renewable electricity.
H.abundance_ru: The most abundant element in the Universe, making up about 75% of all baryonic mass.
fun_facts_ru: The lightest element in the periodic table.
Hydrogen is the primary fuel of stars, including the Sun, through nuclear fusion.
The H₂ molecule is the smallest of all diatomic molecules.

He.industrial_ru: Essential for cryogenics (cooling MRI magnets), welding shielding gas, and filling lighter-than-air balloons.
He.production_ru: Extracted from natural gas deposits where it accumulates from radioactive alpha decay.
He.abundance_ru: Second most abundant element in the Universe, but relatively rare on Earth.
hazards_ru: Can cause asphyxiation in enclosed spaces
fun_facts_ru: Named after Helios, the Greek sun god, because it was first detected in the solar spectrum.
Helium is the only element that cannot be solidified at normal pressure, even at absolute zero.
Below 2.17 K, helium becomes a superfluid that can climb up and over container walls.

Li.industrial_ru: Critical for rechargeable batteries (Li-ion), ceramics, glass, and pharmaceutical mood stabilizers.
Li.production_ru: Extracted from brine pools in salt flats (e.g., in Chile, Argentina) or from spodumene ore by mining.
Li.abundance_ru: Relatively rare in Earth's crust at about 20 ppm, concentrated in certain brine deposits and pegmatite minerals.
fun_facts_ru: The lightest metal and the least dense solid element.
Lithium was one of the three elements produced in the Big Bang nucleosynthesis.
A lithium fire cannot be extinguished with water — it reacts with it.

Be.industrial_ru: Used in aerospace alloys, X-ray windows, and nuclear reactor components due to its stiffness and low neutron absorption.
Be.production_ru: Extracted from the mineral beryl by chemical processing; the United States is the primary producer.
Be.abundance_ru: Rare in Earth's crust at about 2–6 ppm, found mainly in beryl and bertrandite minerals.
fun_facts_ru: Beryllium is transparent to X-rays, making it ideal for X-ray tube windows.
The gemstones emerald and aquamarine are forms of the beryllium mineral beryl.
Despite being a light metal, beryllium is extremely stiff — six times stiffer than steel per unit weight.

B.industrial_ru: Used in borosilicate glass (Pyrex), detergents (borax), fiberglass insulation, and as a neutron absorber in nuclear reactors.
B.production_ru: Mined primarily as borax and kernite deposits; Turkey holds the world's largest reserves.
B.abundance_ru: Relatively scarce in Earth's crust at about 10 ppm, concentrated in evaporite deposits.
hazards_ru: Dust may irritate eyes and respiratory tract
fun_facts_ru: Boron is essential for plant growth but is needed only in trace amounts.
Boron nitride in its cubic form is nearly as hard as diamond.
The element's name comes from the Arabic word 'buraq' for borax.

C.industrial_ru: Foundation of organic chemistry and all known life; used in steel production, fuels, plastics, and advanced materials like carbon fiber and graphene.
C.production_ru: Obtained as coke from coal, charcoal from wood, or as CO₂ from combustion; synthetic diamonds made under high pressure.
C.abundance_ru: Fourth most abundant element in the Universe by mass; forms the basis of all known organic molecules.
hazards_ru: CO and CO₂ are hazardous gases
fun_facts_ru: Carbon exists in multiple allotropes: diamond, graphite, fullerene, graphene, and more.
A single sheet of graphene is the strongest material ever measured.
Carbon-14 dating allows scientists to determine the age of organic materials up to ~50,000 years old.

N.industrial_ru: Used to produce ammonia (fertilizers), explosives, and as an inert atmosphere for food packaging and electronics manufacturing.
N.production_ru: Obtained industrially by fractional distillation of liquid air; comprises 78% of Earth's atmosphere.
N.abundance_ru: Makes up 78% of Earth's atmosphere by volume and is the seventh most abundant element in the Universe.
fun_facts_ru: Nitrogen is essential for all life — it is a key component of amino acids and DNA.
The triple bond in N₂ is one of the strongest chemical bonds, making nitrogen gas very inert.
Lightning converts atmospheric nitrogen into nitrates, naturally fertilizing the soil.

O.industrial_ru: Essential for steelmaking, medical respiration, welding (oxy-acetylene), wastewater treatment, and rocket propulsion.
O.production_ru: Produced industrially by fractional distillation of liquid air; also generated by electrolysis of water.
O.abundance_ru: The most abundant element in Earth's crust (46% by mass) and third most abundant in the Universe.
fun_facts_ru: Oxygen makes up about 21% of Earth's atmosphere and is essential for aerobic life.
Liquid oxygen is pale blue and is strongly attracted to magnets (paramagnetic).
The ozone layer (O₃) in the stratosphere protects life from harmful ultraviolet radiation.

F.industrial_ru: Used in uranium enrichment (UF₆), Teflon (PTFE) production, refrigerants, toothpaste, and pharmaceuticals.
F.production_ru: Produced by electrolysis of a molten mixture of potassium fluoride and hydrogen fluoride (KF·2HF).
F.abundance_ru: The 13th most abundant element in Earth's crust, found mainly in fluorite (CaF₂) and fluorapatite.
fun_facts_ru: Fluorine is the most electronegative and most reactive of all elements.
Many early chemists were injured or killed attempting to isolate fluorine.
Fluoride in small amounts strengthens tooth enamel and prevents cavities.

Ne.industrial_ru: Used in neon signs, high-voltage indicators, cryogenic refrigeration, and helium-neon lasers.
Ne.production_ru: Obtained as a byproduct of air liquefaction; present in the atmosphere at about 18 ppm.
Ne.abundance_ru: Fifth most abundant element in the Universe, but rare in Earth's atmosphere at only 18.2 ppm.
fun_facts_ru: True neon signs glow reddish-orange; other colors use different gases or phosphor coatings.
Neon has the narrowest liquid range of any element — only 2.6 degrees.
Neon's name comes from the Greek word 'neos' meaning 'new'.

Na.industrial_ru: Used in sodium-vapor lamps, as a coolant in nuclear reactors, and to produce sodium compounds like NaOH and NaCl for industry.
Na.production_ru: Produced by electrolysis of molten sodium chloride (Downs process).
Na.abundance_ru: The sixth most abundant element in Earth's crust (2.3%); found in huge deposits of halite (rock salt).
fun_facts_ru: Sodium is soft enough to cut with a knife and light enough to float on water — but it reacts explosively with it.
Sodium-vapor lamps produce the characteristic yellow glow of many street lights.
The human body contains about 100 grams of sodium, essential for nerve function.

Mg.industrial_ru: Used in lightweight alloys for cars and aircraft, fireworks and flares, and as a structural metal in electronics casings.
Mg.production_ru: Produced by electrolysis of molten magnesium chloride or by the Pidgeon process (thermal reduction of MgO).
Mg.abundance_ru: The eighth most abundant element in Earth's crust; abundant in seawater and minerals like dolomite and magnesite.
fun_facts_ru: Magnesium burns with such an intense white light that it was once used in camera flash powder.
Magnesium is essential for chlorophyll, the molecule that makes plants green.
About 0.13% of seawater is magnesium, making the oceans an enormous reserve.

Al.industrial_ru: The most widely used non-ferrous metal; used in aircraft, cars, beverage cans, construction, and electrical wiring.
Al.production_ru: Produced from bauxite ore by the Bayer process (to alumina) followed by the Hall-Heroult electrolysis process.
Al.abundance_ru: The most abundant metal in Earth's crust (about 8%), but never found as a free metal in nature.
fun_facts_ru: Before the Hall-Heroult process (1886), aluminium was more expensive than gold.
Aluminium is 100% recyclable with no loss of quality, and recycling uses only 5% of the energy of primary production.
The Washington Monument is capped with a 2.8 kg aluminium pyramid, placed in 1884 when aluminium was still precious.

Si.industrial_ru: Foundation of the semiconductor industry (computer chips); also used in glass, cement, silicones, and solar cells.
Si.production_ru: Produced by reducing quartz (SiO₂) with carbon in an electric arc furnace; ultra-pure silicon made by the Czochralski process.
Si.abundance_ru: The second most abundant element in Earth's crust (about 28%), after oxygen.
fun_facts_ru: Silicon Valley is named after the element, which is the basis of all modern computer chips.
Silicon is the eighth most abundant element in the Universe by mass.
Silicon and carbon are in the same group, yet carbon-based life dominates over hypothetical silicon-based life.

P.industrial_ru: Essential for fertilizers (phosphates), detergents, matches, steel production, and pesticides.
P.production_ru: Produced from phosphate rock (apatite) by thermal reduction in an electric furnace or by wet acid treatment.
P.abundance_ru: The 11th most abundant element in Earth's crust; found primarily in apatite mineral deposits.
hazards_ru: White phosphorus is extremely toxic and flammable
fun_facts_ru: White phosphorus glows in the dark due to chemiluminescence — the origin of the word 'phosphorescence'.
Phosphorus is essential for life: it is a key component of DNA, RNA, and ATP.
The element was discovered in 1669 by Hennig Brand, who isolated it from urine.

S.industrial_ru: Used to produce sulfuric acid (the most-produced industrial chemical), rubber vulcanization, fungicides, and fertilizers.
S.production_ru: Recovered from natural gas and petroleum refining (Claus process); also mined from native sulfur deposits.
S.abundance_ru: The 10th most abundant element in the Universe; found in volcanic regions and as metal sulfide ores.
hazards_ru: SO₂ and H₂S are toxic gases
fun_facts_ru: Sulfur has been known since antiquity and was called 'brimstone' in the Bible.
Sulfuric acid is often called the 'king of chemicals' — global production exceeds 200 million tonnes per year.
Io, a moon of Jupiter, is covered in sulfur and sulfur dioxide, giving it a yellow-orange color.

Cl.industrial_ru: Used for water purification, PVC plastics production, bleach, disinfectants, and manufacturing of numerous organic chemicals.
Cl.production_ru: Produced by electrolysis of brine (sodium chloride solution) via the chlor-alkali process.
Cl.abundance_ru: The 21st most abundant element in Earth's crust; abundant in seawater as dissolved chloride ions.
fun_facts_ru: Chlorine was the first chemical weapon used in warfare (World War I, 1915).
About 85% of pharmaceutical drugs contain or are manufactured using chlorine chemistry.
Table salt (NaCl) is the most familiar chlorine compound, essential for human life.

Ar.industrial_ru: Used as a shielding gas in welding, in incandescent and fluorescent lighting, and as an inert atmosphere for growing crystals.
Ar.production_ru: Obtained by fractional distillation of liquid air; argon makes up 0.93% of Earth's atmosphere.
Ar.abundance_ru: The third most abundant gas in Earth's atmosphere (0.93%), produced by radioactive decay of potassium-40.
fun_facts_ru: Argon's name comes from the Greek 'argos' meaning 'lazy' or 'idle', reflecting its chemical inertness.
Argon is used to fill the space between double-pane windows for better insulation.
Argon-argon dating is used by geologists to determine the age of rocks and minerals.

K.industrial_ru: Essential for fertilizers (potash), soap production, and as a component in numerous chemical processes.
K.production_ru: Potassium metal is produced by reduction of KCl with sodium; potash fertilizers are mined from evaporite deposits.
K.abundance_ru: The seventh most abundant element in Earth's crust (2.1%), found in minerals like sylvite and orthoclase.
fun_facts_ru: Potassium was the first metal isolated by electrolysis, by Humphry Davy in 1807.
Bananas are famously rich in potassium, but potatoes actually contain more per serving.
The potassium-40 isotope in your body makes you slightly radioactive — about 4,400 disintegrations per second.

Ca.industrial_ru: Used in cement and concrete production, steelmaking (as a deoxidizer), and as a reducing agent for other metals.
Ca.production_ru: Produced by electrolysis of molten calcium chloride; calcium compounds are mined from limestone and gypsum deposits.
Ca.abundance_ru: The fifth most abundant element in Earth's crust (about 3.6%), forming vast limestone and chalk deposits.
fun_facts_ru: The human body contains about 1 kg of calcium, 99% of which is in bones and teeth.
Calcium is essential for muscle contraction, nerve signaling, and blood clotting.
The White Cliffs of Dover are made of calcium carbonate (chalk) from ancient marine organisms.

Fe.industrial_ru: The most important structural metal; used in steel for construction, vehicles, machinery, and tools. Also used in magnets and catalysts.
Fe.production_ru: Smelted from iron ore (hematite, magnetite) in blast furnaces using coke as a reducing agent.
Fe.abundance_ru: The fourth most abundant element in Earth's crust and the most abundant element on Earth overall (by mass, in the core).
fun_facts_ru: Earth's magnetic field is generated by convection currents in the liquid iron outer core.
Iron is the heaviest element produced by stellar nucleosynthesis in massive stars before they explode as supernovae.
The Iron Age began around 1200 BCE and transformed human civilization through stronger tools and weapons.

Cu.industrial_ru: Essential for electrical wiring, plumbing, electronics, and as an alloying element in bronze and brass.
Cu.production_ru: Extracted from sulfide ores (chalcopyrite) by smelting and electrolytic refining; also by leaching and solvent extraction.
Cu.abundance_ru: Makes up about 50 ppm of Earth's crust; found in large deposits in Chile, Peru, and the USA.
hazards_ru: Compounds can irritate skin and eyes
fun_facts_ru: Copper was one of the first metals used by humans, dating back over 10,000 years.
The Statue of Liberty is covered with about 80 tonnes of copper, which has turned green from oxidation.
Copper has natural antimicrobial properties — bacteria die within hours on copper surfaces.

Zn.industrial_ru: Used for galvanizing steel to prevent rust, in brass alloys, batteries (zinc-carbon and alkaline), and zinc oxide in sunscreens.
Zn.production_ru: Produced from sphalerite (ZnS) ore by roasting to ZnO followed by reduction with carbon or electrolysis.
Zn.abundance_ru: The 24th most abundant element in Earth's crust (about 70 ppm), found primarily in sphalerite deposits.
hazards_ru: Zinc fumes cause metal fume fever
Compounds may be toxic to aquatic life
fun_facts_ru: Zinc is essential for human health — it supports immune function and is found in every cell.
About half of all zinc produced is used for galvanizing, which protects 200 million tonnes of steel annually.
Zinc pennies (post-1982 US cents) are actually 97.5% zinc with a thin copper plating.

Ag.industrial_ru: Used in jewelry, electronics (best electrical conductor), photography, mirrors, solar panels, and antibacterial coatings.
Ag.production_ru: Mined from native silver and silver-bearing ores (argentite); also obtained as a byproduct of copper and lead refining.
Ag.abundance_ru: Rare in Earth's crust at about 0.07 ppm; found in ore deposits across Mexico, Peru, and China.
hazards_ru: Colloidal silver can cause argyria (permanent skin discoloration)
fun_facts_ru: Silver has the highest electrical and thermal conductivity of any element.
The word 'Argentina' comes from the Latin 'argentum' meaning silver.
Silver ions are antimicrobial — silver nanoparticles are used in wound dressings and water purification.

Au.industrial_ru: Used in jewelry, electronics (connectors, circuit boards), dentistry, aerospace coatings, and as a financial reserve asset.
Au.production_ru: Mined from lode deposits and placer deposits; extracted using cyanide leaching or gravity separation.
Au.abundance_ru: Very rare in Earth's crust at about 0.004 ppm; most of Earth's gold sank to the core during planetary formation.
hazards_ru: Some gold compounds can be toxic
fun_facts_ru: All the gold ever mined would fit into a cube about 21 meters on each side.
Gold is so malleable that one ounce can be beaten into a sheet covering 28 square meters.
Gold is formed in neutron star collisions and supernovae — literally stardust.
